Do you know what happens when you "gas" up a car on a dirt track from a 
slow speed to speeding up? You get a pretty significant rooster tail of 
dirt that comes out, and, even though the quality isn't clear enough to 
tell with 100% certainty, there does not look to be any such rooster tail 
of dirt.
It's also very clear that Stewart was going straight until his rear tire 
hit an object (Ward) and his car was pulled toward that direction.
So even IF he "gassed" his car up, that does not put any blame on him for, 
again I will say this, the dumbass walking on a track while there is a race 
in progress getting in his way from out of nowhere.

+sglider
No, I'm claiming that cars bumping and one doing what Ward's car did would 
not be silent. You're saying that the camera mic is powerful enough to pick 
up sound accurately from that distance, but not accurate enough to pick up 
the sound of that incident. It can't be both. The mic can't both be good 
and not good.

He was walking onto a track that had a race in progress.

+sglider
"Well, the video I'm watching shows the same kid get out of his car, walk 
to the back of it, take about three steps down the track and then take 
about ten steps forward, stops, steps down about two steps, points his 
finger, takes another half step forward, leans to the left back up the 
track and then gets run over by Stewart"  There ya go. We agree. The 
dumbass walked onto a race track. and got clipped by a rear driving tire, 
which ended up causing his own death.  Very simple case.

As for your comment on the sound, you really think that the sounds of the 
cars at race speed (the beginning of the clip) are the same sounds the 
engines make on a yellow flag? Really?  If the sounds carry that well from 
that distance, you're saying that the Ward crash into the wall, the near 
flip, was all magically silent? Oh, I know, it was covered up by the engine 
sounds. SO I get it now. The sounds carry when it's convenient for you to 
validate what you already think, but when it doesn't match, then "there's a 
different reason for that" type of explanation.

credentials established, in my laymen's perspective, it appears to me that 
Mr. Ward jumped in front of Mr. Stewart's car.  Mr. Ward made what appears 
to be a very ill-advised decision - to run into the middle of a track with 
oncoming traffic, apparently to make a point as Mr. Stewart drove by. 
 Unfortunately for both parties, Mr. Ward ran too low onto the track, as 
Mr. Stewart drove high enough (I will not say "too high", because he was 
still well within the flow of traffic), causing the two to connect.  It is 
my laymen's OPINION that Mr. Stewart did nothing wrong and did nothing to 
display aggression or unprofessional behavior.  It appears to be nothing 
more than a very tragic accident caused by Mr. Ward's decision to jump into 
traffic to make a point - one that eventually killed him.﻿

You guys do realize that cameras are made to pick up more light in dark 
situations, right? There have been recorded incidents of times when drivers 
have run dead into black painted cars without ever having known the car was 
there. Ward was in a full black suit, which would be fairly hard for 
Stewart to make out. (Let's remember that a helmet limits some of your 
view, and as well, you're busy with the lights in the cockpit, and the 
people infront and behind you.) 

Now, the allegation that Tony rev'ed up and hit him.
Well, yes, Tony did accelerate, but please go ahead and looks up other 
sprint car videos. Under caution, when exiting a corner, you jump the 
throttle some to point the car out straight. This is just a common thing in 
sprint cars because of the rear wheel stagger, as the stagger makes the car 
want to continue to roll left. As well, this is a dirt track. Dirt is very 
unpredictable due to the way it can develop bumps and ruts and holes.

Also, sure Kevin Ward did the NASCAR thing of coming down the race track a 
bit and pointing, but you never, under any circumstances, get within 2-3 
feet of a moving car, whether it's a race car or not. If you watch NASCAR 
videos of drivers getting upset at one another and pointing, they stay 
about 10 feet away at all times, and are on brightly lit racetracks, most 
of the time in the middle of the day, wearing bright colored suits. There 
is a line you DO NOT CROSS when you are around race cars, and Kevin crossed 
the line and got way too close, and therefore was struck by Tony's car and 
killed.﻿

The Ontario County sheriff's department is continuing its investigation 
into Kevin Ward Jr.'s death.  Law enforcement officials have not concluded 
this was an accident.  Sheriff Povero has said the department has two 
videos shot from different points of view, and is asking any other 
spectators with video to present it to the department.  He's said the 
investigation could take at least two more weeks to complete.  I understand 
both Tony's and Kevin's fans, and others, will keep defending each driver, 
and all have made salient points.  But as far as Tony Stewart's future 
goes--his actual future, not just his reputation--the Ontario County 
Sheriff and District Attorney, and perhaps a jury of Tony's peers, have yet 
to weigh in.  And their conclusions will be very weighty indeed, more so 
than any comments made here. ﻿

Okay, reality check. In criminal law, Ward's intent or stupidity don't 
matter. All that matters is Stewart's intent. Did he intend to cause harm? 
OR did he have "depraved indifference?"

To prosecute, you have to be able to prove one or the other beyond a 
reasonable doubt. You simply can't do that from this tape. SOMEBODY revved 
their engine. Was it even Stewart? You can't tell from the tape. Did he hit 
the kid or did the kid lunge or trip? Again, you can't tell from the tape. 
You can tell the kid was being dragged--and apparently rolled. But you 
can't tell whether he's hung up on the side irons or what.

Unless witnesses--or Stewart--have something conclusive to say, a 
prosecution is a waste of time. And the police were pretty quick definite 
in saying there was no such evidence, at least as yet.

Of course, Ward's parents CAN sue in civil court--for wrongful death or 
some such. But in such a case, Ward's actions DO come into play. In a 
"tort" lawsuit, he's required to act responsibly too, not just Stewart. 
Again, you can't tell from the tape even whether Stewart actually hit the 
kid or even whether Ward tripped or even leaped into the car. (No, it would 
be pretty preposterous for him to attack a moving sprint car. But "would 
be" doesn't count in a court of law. Something has to be actually proven.)

So again, unless witnesses come forward with evidence we haven't seen/heard 
yet, a lawsuit is a pretty long shot as well.

Anything beyond that, at this stage, is just talk. Big talk. Loose talk. 
Uninformed talk. But just talk.

Nothing about that makes this any less a tragedy, though. ﻿

I have no choice but to fault Tony on this and I've watched Sprint Car 
racing on half mile dirt tracks for years.

Yes, Kevin Ward Jr. would still be alive today if he had stayed in his 
vehicle, but drivers exit their cars to confront other drivers all of the 
time in racing, especially on small dirt tracks like this one. For Kevin to 
walk down the track and confront Tony is not at all unusual, especially 
when you consider that it is a caution and these cars are clipping along at 
35 mph instead of 160 mph.

What is unusual is to see and hear Tony stab the throttle (under caution) a 
split second before apparently sideswiping Kevin with his right rear tire 
and spitting him up the track at a high rate of speed. According to Paul 
Kinney, who drove by Kevin Ward a few seconds before Tony approached, Kevin 
could be seen as clear as day, so I'm not buying that Tony never saw him. 
From what I understand, these two did have a history and everyone knows 
Tony has a serious temper.

I'm not saying he intentionally hit the kid, but in my opinion the fact 
that he failed to move lower on the track to avoid a collision (as every 
other driver was able to do) AND stabbed the throttle right before impact 
makes him more than eligible to be charged with involuntary vehicular 
manslaughter.

Quite frankly, Kevin Ward Jr. did not walk right in front of Tonys' car. 
I'm willing to concede that the kid, while young, was smart enough not to 
just commit suicide on the track. If Tony hadn't stabbed the throttle, I'm 
convinced that either Kevin never would've been hit or his injury would've 
been far less than fatal. That makes Tony Stewart liable.﻿

The grand jury's decision was not the least bit surprising.  The primary 
piece of evidence was this video, and it clearly shows the following:

1.  Stewart's car was moving at approximately the same speed as the other 
cars ahead.
2.  Stewart's car was appropriately positioned on the track, only about 1/2 
a car width higher than the 45 car directly ahead of it.
3.  Numerous other cars were as high on the track as Stewart's, and at 
least one was higher.
4.  After exiting his car, Ward initially remained high on the track and 
waited for cars to pass.  Only when Stewart's car got close did Ward walk 
down into the middle of the track.
5.  Ward positioned himself in the path of exactly ONE car... Stewart's #14.
6.  Stewart's car did not deviate from its line until after contacting Ward.
7.  Immediately after contacting Ward, Stewart's car fishtailed to the 
LEFT, away from Ward.
8.  Ward either intentionally grabbed or somehow got snagged on the right 
spoiler wing of Stewart's car, and from there he fell and was struck by the 
right rear tire.

It's amazing how many people there are who lack the intellect (or eyesight) 
to recognize all of the above.﻿

Ok, first off you need to understand that steering a sprint car is totally 
different than a real car. A lot of your turning is done using the gas and 
sliding. That's how you pass people in this race. Stewart had the lead on 
Ward and was drifting up the track as most do when they turn. If Ward would 
have just backed off the gas like he should have, there would have been no 
wreck. Second off, in a sprint car the right fin is tucked down so far, all 
you can see is maybe the waist down on a person. You can see left, but not 
right. Third, drivers are supposed to remain in the car unless it's on 
fire. I can understand since they are burning alcohol that he got out 
because he may not be able to tell. But Ward is a complete dipshit for 
walking back into oncoming traffic when they can't see to the right anyway.

walk back into traffic. There is absolutely nobody to blame except Ward in 
this case. Definitely deserves a Darwin award.﻿

Allow me to be as blunt as possible to anyone who still thinks Tony Stewart 
is guilty: You need your head examined.

Let's point out the sequence of events as the video happens:
- At 0:05, observe that there is a slower lapped car on the bottom of the 
racetrack. The car is still on the bottom when Kevin Ward Jr hits the wall.
- At 0:07, notice that Ward's car gets loose and hits the wall right rear 
first. Also notice that Ward was carrying too much speed, and had he slowed 
down just a little, he would have been able to attempt a crossover 
beginning at Turn Three.
- Note the extensive damage to the right rear at 0:14
- At 0:33, two things need to be observed: First, the #45 car almost hits 
Ward, only just missing him. You will see him swerve to avoid him. Also, 
the black suit and black helmet that he is wearing makes him close to 
invisible for oncoming traffic. There is a reason you are instructed when 
you are little to attach neon tape to your clothing or wear bright colors, 
and that is because darker colors are close to impossible to see at night, 
especially with a dimly lit backstretch such as this racetrack has.
- At 0:35, when Kevin Ward is hit, Tony Stewart's car steers to the right 
because he ran over Ward. At no time did he turn into him.
- Ward was still wearing his helmet when he charged onto the track. What 
needs to be found out is if the infield crew was instructing Ward to STAY 
IN HIS FUCKING CAR, and either he chose to ignore it or his helmet was 
impairing his vision and hearing, and therefore made him oblivious to the 
demands of the infield crew. These cars fly around like candy bar wrappers 
when they wreck, and you are to stay in your car if your car wrecks to the 
degree that Ward's did.

Tony Stewart did not kill Kevin Ward. Kevin Ward got Kevin Ward killed

one million times more important than Kevin Ward's own safety.﻿

I remember back in the early days when I lived in Denver. We used to go 
East off 128th St. and I-25 to a sprint car track called Race land. The 
track as I remember was an old half mile dirt track which had been modified 
to 7/8 of a mile. Back in those days those sprints were called champ cars 
with wings and big block chevy engines. A bit bigger than the regular sized 
super sprint cars that are driven in the World of Outlaws
of today. I remember Tony Bentenhausen? got put into the wall on the last 
lap and was clearly leading the race for the win. After he got put into the 
wall he stayed in his car till the race ended. After that he climbed out of 
his car and headed to the pits to settle up with the guy who put him into 
the wall. This particular race was an official USAC race and if any of the 
USAC field marshals seen any unsportsmanlike conduct on the track or in the 
pits they would fine you points in your race standings. As much as we all 
love the sport and thrill of auto racing it still remains a very dangerous 
sport. It's too bad that what happened didn't have to end the way it did. 
Thank you all for your comments on You Tube!﻿

Today is day #34 since the incident. #14 has yet to offer a defense of 
himself. #14 has yet to offer a plausible explanation. #14 does not act 
like somebody who has the truth on his side that is going to set him free 
from responsibility.  The District Attorney has not issued a dismissal. 
Thus one can conclude that it's not a clear cut dismissal. District

I don't like NASCAR, don't know either of the drivers, or their tempers or 
histories so I look at this incident objectively.  I find with all this 
split hatred for Stewart and Ward, I need to add my perspective to this 
matter.  

1. Ward should have never left that car unless there was a life threatening 
reason. ie fire.

2. It was number 14 that cut him off causing him to hit the wall.

3. He stands in the track and then abruptly skips a few steps forward 
(inward) as the 45 car passes close by.

4. The 14 car, Mr. Stewart, now has a second to react to the presence of 
Mr. Ward.

5. Stewart collides with Ward, resulting in Wards death.

Now, taking into account the accident happened on the outside of the 
corner, all cars exiting that corner would be focused on the inside while 
drifting.  Mr. Ward being on the 45 cars right hand side would also hide 
him from view of the approaching cars momentarily and by the time Stewart 
would have seen him a second for reaction time is an impossibility in a 
race on dirt at that speed.  My final verdict is that this was an 
unfortunate accident partially caused by negligence on Mr. Wards part.﻿

This is something where, your kid does something stupid, you pull him 
aside, and say "don't do that again, you could get yourself killed". 
 Unfortunately this is a situation where a kid does get killed and it's too 
late.  It's impossible to tell Tony's intentions in this video, so we 
should all stop trying to make conclusions from it.  However, though not 
impossible, it's far less believable that anyone would murder another 
person in front of a hundred spectators than it simply being an accident. 
 It's a night race, on dirt, and the kid was wearing black clothing.  But 
if you are going to make conclusions based on this video alone.  The nature 
of the crash suggests this is a fast turn.  His car was taking up some of 
the lane and he walked down half way.  He was trying to obscure Tony's path 
and it seems to me that he didn't see him in time.  ﻿

I don't understand why people are so shocked to see Ward run onto the track 
and Tony shouldn't have been either. Tony is in a sport where his 
competitors bounce of one another until the finally wreck. Then once they 
have wrecked they proceed to fight with one another on track or in the 
pits. Hell their have even been instances where drivers have ran at the 
opposing car and thrown their helmet at them. This isn't something new to 
Tony, he has seen this stuff in the past. Furthermore, you can't tell me a 
caution flag wasn't thrown after this wreck, you can see the cars slowing 
down. Even in basic racing school they tell you to avoid the wreck, or 
drive on the opposite side of it. Then, to top that all off, why was he so 
high up? I get the track is poorly light, I get the corner is blind BUT 
they we're just involved in a wreck, Tony KNEW the car was there. Even if 
Kevin was still inside the car why on earth would you drive so close to the 
accident when everyone else is driving near the bottom of the track. Not to 
mention, this isn't the first time a driver has gotten out of their car on 
a dirt track. Everyone acts like this never happens, racers typically get 
out of their car as emergency crews come over. Tony is a professional 
driver who made some ill advised decisions, just as Kevin did. 
Nevertheless, anyway you cut it this isn't going to have a good outcome for 
Tony. If he isn't charged people and drivers will still remember this 
incident for the rest of his career.﻿

The backlash against Stewart has seriously depressed me. It's made me 
realise that there's very little hope for humanity because the power of 
peoples' egos exceeds the power of their intelligence. I'm going to try and 
explain as best as I can why you all should stop calling Stewart a 
murderer...

Empathy is important here, because if you put yourself in Stewart's 
position, you'll understand while calling him a murderer is ludicrous. And 
when I say put yourself in his position, I don't just mean behind the 
wheel; I mean know the backstory, know how to operate a sprint car, etc.
First off, if it's so easy to swerve out of the way of a person, why do 
people get hit by cars all the time? Hell, why do car accidents happen at 
all if they're so easy to avoid?
Take into consideration that people get hit by accident who AREN'T walking 
into traffic. Take into consideration that people get hit by accident by 
cars that AREN'T on dirt tracks.
Stewart claims he didn't even know Ward. Stewart's had longtime rivalries 
with several drivers whom he DOES know. Jeff Gordon, Joey Logano, Jimmie 
Johnson, Kyle Busch. Why on Earth would he have so much pent up road rage 
for someone he doesn't know as opposed to someone he has history having 
road rage towards? There's no motive.
People who claim he's a murderer need to take some psychology courses. It's 
ridiculous to call him a murderer when a premeditated murder isn't a split 
second decision like what this video displays. Considering Ward broke 
direct racing rules and etiquette by exiting his vehicle and walking into 
traffic, seeing a person on a race course isn't something any driver is 
expecting. Had Stewart planned to hit him, he would have had to think as 
fast as he had time to react, for which murder and recklessness really 
REALLY don't apply.
In addition to that, seeing a person on the race track wearing a helmet and 
through your own helmet, it's insane for anyone to assume Stewart even knew 
it was Ward, whom as I stated before, he didn't even know anyway. Why would 
Stewart decide to hit a person on the track when it really could have been 
anybody just wandering out into traffic?
Sprint cars are also not normal cars. They don't operate like your Accord. 
In order to properly empathise with Stewart behind the wheel of a sprint 
car, it's important to acknowledge that you definitely wouldn't be able to 
drive one yourself. They're designed to turn on dirt at high speeds. Anyone 
who's seen the Pixar movie "Cars" should understand the effects of turning 
on dirt at high speeds. Sprint cars turn by drifting. This is why the rear 
tire is what hit Ward. Stewart didn't turn into him, and he certainly 
didn't go at him head-on. He was turning to avoid him in probably what 
little time he had to see him.
Stewart took several races off, and has avoided the press until very 
recently. Someone who did something like hit another person with a car 
intentionally wouldn't avoid the public eye once they were "caught 
red-handed." He obviously is very shaken up about the incident. And if 
you've ever seen older interviews with Stewart, you'll know he's not easily 
saddened, and far from shy.
Lastly, Ward could very well have been high. Take it with a grain of salt, 
but still worth noting. Maybe he was sober during the race, maybe not. 
We'll never know for sure.

Really, I just want people to stop being so ignorant. If you don't like 
Stewart, fine. Who cares? Lots of people have hated him for a really long 
time. But just because you don't, you can't go calling him a murderer just 
because of what you think about him. You don't know him outside of what 
you've read or seen on TV. Imagine if you accidentally killed someone and 
everyone started calling you a murderer for it. Give it a rest, folks.﻿

The audio of this video gives false audio evidence from the back-stretch, 
you are hearing car sounds from the front-stretch. The camera man's video 
is zooming from in the crowd, outside the oval, across the moving cars on 
the front-stretch track, then across the infield to right up close to the 
wreck on the back-stretch of the half mile track??. The audio mic on the 
camera doesn't have the ability to zoom. The cars going by the 
front-stretch would drown out any sound coming from the back stretch. The 
alleged revving sound of Stewart's engine(powerslide to the right) was more 
likely an unseen car on the front-stretch revving his motor. Slow motion 
video shows Stewart's car didn't stray in direction until after Ward was 
clear of the front wheel of Stewart's car. The crazed man running into fast 
moving traffic was dressed in black, I thought the blue car in front of

I think everyone needs to watch the video a little more closely before 
placing blame on Stewart. When Kevin gets out of his car he walks around 
the rear end to the passenger side. As soon as he is on the passenger side 
of his car, the first car that passes Kevin is the closest car to pass the 
13. It passes closer and faster than anyone else, which keeps Kevin high on 
the track. As soon as that car passes by, a second car passes by. Then 
there is a 2.5 second gap. That's when Kevin begins to walk towards the 
infield. Kevin walks past the middle of the track. That's when the 45 car 
passes Kevin. Yo can see Kevin had to hop out of the way of the 45 car. You 
can also see that the 45 car's trajectory is that he is coming from the 
center towards the inside to avoid making contact. In fact, you can see the 
45 car's wing "wiggle" when the driver straightens the wheel after making 
his corrective maneuver to avoid Kevin. The 45 car's 2.5 second gap was big 
enough from the car in front of him to allow him more time to react to what 
Kevin was doing. After the 45 goes by, Kevin steps even further towards the 
inside with his right leg. His feet are perpendicular with the traffic 
direction. Stewart did not have as big of a gap in front of him that the 45 
car had in front of them. It was only about 1.2 seconds. Also Stewarts line 
was only about a third of a car higher then where the 45 car was running 
before the 45 made his move to the inside to avoid Kevin. Also, the 45 car 
screened Kevin from Stewarts view until the 45 was past him. I say this 
because they were in the middle of turn 2. Anyone that drives a car can 
visualize how during a left turn, a car in front of you blocks the view of 
objects that are on the right side until the car in front of you passes 
said object. That would give Stewart only 1.2 seconds to recognize, assess 
and react to what Kevin was doing. That is virtually the blink of an eye. 
Stewart did the only thing he could do to avoid contact. He tried to kick 
the rear of the car to the left by hitting the gas. He didn't have the 
luxury of 2.5 seconds that the 45 car had to avoid contact. 

Another point I would like to make is about the mindset of Kevin Ward. Here 
is this kid that has been racing sprints for a quarter of his life. I'm 
sure he felt like there is nothing anyone could tell him about sprints that 
he already didn't know. I'm sure he considered himself a veteran to the car 
class that has worked his ass off every race for the past 5 years to 
establish himself as someone that commands respect from the other drivers. 
So it's not too difficult to understand how pissed off he got when this 
"so-called" professional driver that earns millions of dollars driving 
elsewhere, comes to his house and puts him into the wall. That is what 
fueled Kevin's emotions and made him decide that he was going to tolerate 
being wrecked. In Kevin's head, he was going to tell punk-ass Stewart that 
he was in HIS house and make sure Stewart understood that very fact. Well, 
that little temper tantrum was the reason for his demise. He put himself in 
harms way because he allowed his ego-fueled tirade to get the best of him. 
The fact of the matter is that he would still be alive if he stayed in his 
car. Simple as that. 

The whole thing is really senseless. Stewart was just racing when they got 
together in the first place. You can tell that Stewart was setting himself 
up to try to make a pass on the car in front of him when they wrecked. The 
car in front of him was running the inside line going around the turn. 
Stewart went into the turn running the middle line so that he could 
possibly make a run on the outside of the car in front of him. Kevin tried 
to make a third line outside of Stewart. The track isn't big enough to run 
a third outside line. He should have realized that he didn't have enough 
car on Stewart to make Stewart yield the position. Impatience put himself 
in a bad spot in the first place and he ended up on the short end of the 
stick because of it. 

In the end, I do feel sorry for Kevin and his family. I don't wish death on 
anyone. But there is only so much condolences that I can give because this 
was his own damn fault. ﻿

Veteran race fans remember a rookie driver who jumped out of his car during 
a NASCAR race in 1999 after another driver spun his car into him in 
Martinsville, Virginia. That driver was Tony Stewart.

Stewart had traded bumps throughout the race with Kenny Irwin, who had been 
his dirt-track rival before they both moved up to NASCAR.

But the last crash against the wall disabled Stewart's car. Stewart waited 
on the track for Irwin to circle around under a caution flag. Stewart threw 
his gloves at Irwin's car, and jumped onto its right side while the car was 
still moving.

ONE QUESTION: Which way does the back end of Stewart's car move when he 
guns it?? Watch the video. The back end swerves TO THE LEFT, away from 
Kevin Ward, Jr., which would seem to indicate Stewart was trying to avoid 
hitting him, but the maneuver was not in time. Too many commenters here 
don't seem to understand throttle steering. I am not a Tony Stewart fan, 
but I don't know how anyone watching this video could come to the 
conclusion that he deliberately hit Ward or was trying to brush him back, 
swipe him, or spray dirt. The video doesn't support that and seems to show 
exactly the opposite. If there is anything to be blamed for the accident, I 
would think it was Ward's poor judgment in leaving his vehicle, recklessly 
running into the field of traffic, and then challenging an oncoming vehicle 
(on a dirt track!!). Very sorry for the family's loss and pretty sure it 
was an accident.﻿

For people that know racing, especially sprints, know they are extremely 
fast. We are talking in the number of 900+horse power. So put a sprint on a 
dirt track with slick tires and what do you get. An car moving fast 
drifting (sliding) around the track. 

So let's ask some questions. Why did he give the car gas as he came around 
to Kevin. Let's put into play that Tony didn't see Kevin. But he did see 
the car in front of him swerve to miss something on the track. So to turn 
these cars on a dime you can't just turn the wheel. Doing so would make the 
car slide or spin out. Same result. If you slam on the brakes. Same issue 
slide or spin out. Still an issue. So I need to get my sprint car to turn 
now. I goose the gas and turn the wheel. Causes the rear end to come out a 
bit and turn the car. 

Now visually. How could of he not seen Kevin. Well let's talk visibility. 
It's dark. It's dirt. Worse mostly all black, and he ran in front of Tony 
expecting him to stop. You have a better chance getting a train to stop 
then a sprint with slick tires on a slick track.

I rarely choose to comment, but feel compelled...  Drivers have gotten out 
of their cars following wrecks under the caution flag since racing began 
and rarely have been killed for doing so.  Yes, there is an inherent risk 
in walking out on the track, but it is just silly to blame the kid.  This 
boy didn't die because he got out of his car.  He didn't die because he was 
wearing a black racing suit.  He died because he was hit by another car... 
period.  People should wait until getting the "facts" and hope the truth 
eventually comes out to determine an overall cause and how it can be 
prevented in the future (the new rules resulting will certainly help). 
Until then, people would be better off keeping their opinions to 
themselves. 

The circumstances may indeed prove it to be simply a horrible accident, 
which will only come from Tony Stuart.  Perhaps he didn't see him (which 
could have been contributed to him wearing a dark racing suit?).  Or,

Again, only 2 people know and only one is around to provide any details.

very little, so I won't offer mine (though I do have a little racing 
insight).  However, I do know that regardless of ultimate outcome, Stuart 
would not intentionally plan to injure and certainly not kill another 
driver, especially a young 20yr old kid.  His actions may have contributed 
to his death, but Stuart fan or not, it is just common sense to understand 
that this was not deliberate.  But, I have read very little common sense

I'm no authority on Sprint cars but a couple of things I see in this video. 
Tony's car fishtails out immediately before impact which would indicate he 
was making an evasive maneuver to the left or inside of the track. Sprint 
cars rely heavily on downforce generated by the massive wings for traction. 
This requires speed to generate this downforce which may explain why Tony 
didnt slam on the brakes (I'm not a sprint car driver so I don't presume to 
know what actions would be best for an evasive maneuver under those 
conditions).

I could see where a person who knows nothing about racing in general could 
see this video and think, "Holy shit, Tony Stewart killed this kid."  
However, a few points to add to this argument.  First off, it doesn't 
matter if you go low or high into a corner, 99% of the time, the driver 
will end up going high into the straight away, which is exactly what 
Stewart was doing.  The kid should have seen that he didn't have the room 
to clear the corner and backed off the throttle.  Stewart has raced several 
times, both Nascar and Sprint racing and you see this stuff all the 
time...cars that are in front always try to keep their lead on the person 
in front of them.  Secondly, Stewart doesn't swerve to the right to hit 
Ward.  He is going pretty straight into the corner, but when his right back 
wheel catches Ward, it causes his front wheels to turn to the right.  
Anyone ever had a rear flat tire go out when you are on the highway...same 
concept.  Plus, I can tell you it's not very easy to see out of those 
vehicles.  I don't think Stewart knew the kid was out of his car, because 
he was on the other side of the track when he got out.  I am not a fan of 
Stewart, but he is a professional, and he would not put his ENTIRE career 
in jeopardy by attempting to scare a 20 year old on a Sprint track...use 
your head people.﻿
